Bedford-Stuyvesant Clinics, Part 2

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This recording appears to be part two of the recording "Urban League Presents: Bedford-Stuyvesant Looks to Psychiatric Needs" on AV523. It is unclear whether this recording ever aired on WNYU.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: This tape is related to materials in RG 39.5, Records of WNYU (Radio Station: New York, N.Y.). Also see ref140 (AV523): Urban League Presents: Bedford-Stuyvesant Looks to Psychiatric Needs in AV collection

did.unittitle: Pipes and Pedals of New York

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: This tape is related to materials in RG 39.5, Records of WNYU (Radio Station: New York, N.Y.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This recording concerns the history of organ instruments. It was created by the Documentary Unit of the Communications Arts Group and broadcasted on WNYU. The host was Walt Michaels and the organist player featured on the recording is Dick Wolitoch.

phystech.head: Physical/Technical notes
phystech.p: Recorded on Scotch Magnetic Tape (3M) at 7 1/2 IPS.

did.unittitle: The Irish Muse: An Evening of Readings New York University Producer: Elisa Guarino
Various recordings of and relating to Richard Nixon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This recording includes the complete resignation speech of former U.S. President Richard Nixon, as well as clips from NBC, CBS, and ABC news coverage of the event.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: This recording was donated by the Office of Media Production.

did.unittitle: Various recordings of footage from the Richard Nixon presidency

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This recording includes footage of Richard Nixon during his presidency, as well as interviews with Bella Abzug, Gabe Pressman, and New York University School of Law Dean Robert McKay. It also includes footage of Gerald Ford being sworn in as Vice President, and the appointment of Henry Kissinger as Secretary of State.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: This recording was donated by the Office of Media Production.

scopecontent.p: Appears to be a jazz/big band radio show from the 1960s or 1970s - possibly a WNYU show? Found on a 1/4" audio tape with a recording of a lecture from Dr. Floyd Zulli's Sunrise Semester class - "Have You Read...?" The subject of the lecture was Thomas Paine's Common Sense.

did.unittitle: Untitled Anatomy lecture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first 7:30 of recording appear to be part of an anatomy class in which the lecturer discusses several bones and muscle groups and even has a drummer perform in order to demonstrate how parts of the body work. Original tape held this recording and two lectures by Floyd Zulli for his "Have You Read...?" class on Sunrise Semester. Recordings on this reel can be identified by Unique Identifiers beginning with 2023.

did.unittitle: Small Time Crooks/Woody Allen Q&A

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the spring of 2000, Woody Allen did a two week tour of colleges and universities around the United States with his film "Small Time Crooks" starting at NYU. This is a video of events surrounding the NYU pre-screening, including students receiving tickets, reacting to the film outside of the theater, and engaging in a Q&A session with Woody Allen. Audio drops out at times when B-Roll audience reaction shots have been inserted to footage of Mr. Allen answering questions. (Preceded by bars and tone)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Episode of a show geared toward teens interested in the arts and humanities. There are large blank spots on the tape probably intended to be filled by commercials. This episode features a segment with Patrick Riviera, Director of the High School Summer Drama Program at Tisch School of the Arts. Patrick participates in a group interview about various summer arts programs for high schoolers. The segment starts at 23:20 and ends at at 28:10.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a brief segment David Letterman did on the Late Show in which he speaks with Tisch School students about acting in their films. It is intercut with short scenes in which Dave plays bit parts, usually getting a laugh.

altformavail.head: Access copy
altformavail.p: Access copy available on DVD: ACCESS 9:5.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a promotional video for the William H. Cosby Future Filmmakers Workshop; a high school summer program at Tisch School of the Arts. It features interviews with alumni of the program and clips from some of the films the students made. "Special Thanks" are given to Clive Davis, Peter Lund and Harvey Weinstein, and William H. Cosby in end credits.

did.unittitle: Episode of Japanese entertainment TV show, "Cinematic Report"

altformavail.head: Access copy
altformavail.p: Access copy available on DVD: ACCESS 9:2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cinematic Report appears to be a Japanese television show focused on the film industry. In addition to reviewing films, this episode features reporting on the top five film undergrad programs in the United States. The segment on NYU's Tisch School begins at 05:22 and is only about twenty seconds long. The report uses footage from the NYU Tisch School of the Arts Recruitment Video made in 1997.

did.unittitle: "NYU On the Air" - Clip Reel of NYU-related segments on TV shows

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: This reel is related to the RG 7.3.4: Records of the Department of Media Production

altformavail.head: Access copy
altformavail.p: Access copy available on DVD: ACCESS 9:8.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Entitled "NYU on the Air," this reel is composed mostly of clips from news shows featuring professors or administrators from NYU. Clips come from The Late Show with David Letterman, Inside the Law, Giraldo Rivera, Legal Cafe, CNN News, CNN Showbiz, Seinfeld, and Cosby. Some of the featured guests are Dean of Stern School of Business George Daly, then Dean of NYU Law School John Sexton, Financial Aid Director Keith Jepsen, Director of Africana Studies Manthia Diawara and President Jay Oliva The reel was produced by the Elisa Guarino in the Department of Media Production and the Office of Public Affairs.

did.unittitle: "Columbia University and New York University Film Schools: Free Film Voices"

altformavail.head: Access copy
altformavail.p: Access copy available on DVD: ACCESS 9:7

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documentary about the pros and cons of going to film school. Should a film maker spend money on the tuition of film school or just make a feature length motion picture for the same cost? These questions are asked and answered by students, alumni, and professors from Tisch School of Arts and Columbia University's film program.

did.unittitle: Marshall McLuhan untitled

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The video quality of this disc is grainy and the volume is makes it difficult to hear exactly what people are saying The setting is a lecture hall Where McLuhan, Nevitt, and various other people are seated facing an audience. In his discussion there is a reference to being at a conference at the School of Dentistry but nothing is truly specified. The men, mainly McLuhan, discuss how environment effects and is effected by technology while the actual technology is incidental. They further talk about technological breakthroughs and how humans perceive it. Intellectual decline from over stimulation from technology creating a "goal-less" child who is more interested in role playing rather than true decision making thanks to television and radio. Most of the discussion is based on McLuahn's "Laws of Media" which is a four part tetrad of things that share an "interlocking nature" when humans consume media. The four parts are Enhance, Reverse, Retrieve, Obsolescence. The film cuts out frequently and ends abruptly.

did.unittitle: Marshall McLuhan Ecology Program

altformavail.head: Access copy
altformavail.p: Access copy available on CD: ACCESS 1:21

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No title of event given or visible. The video quality of this disk is clear and the people speaking within the room are relatively easy to hear and comprehend especially when McLuhan speaks.The tape starts in the middle of a group discussion. The setting is in an office with a large table. The audience participates, asking McLuhan questions and receiving answers from him. The majority of the discussion is based on McLuhans "Laws of Media" which is a four part tetrad of things that share an "interlocking nature" when humans consume media. The four parts are Enhance, Reverse, Retrieve, Obsolescence. His discussion raises concern on mans responsibility for technologies and its effect on humans. He argues that we need studies about technology in order to shape them properly for consumption. Part of his argument is about adverting in the American home as opposed to foreign advertising which is much less prevalent in private lives. He also discusses the effects of politicians becoming visually and verbally known by the general public. The discussion ends with the conclusion that our current media is an open game meaning that nothing is finalized. McLuhan concludes that he does not believe there is a solidified answer to his questions. Instead he views it as a continued exploration. The film ends with questions from the audience where McLuhan fields questions, takes business cards, and hands back his portable mic he was using.

bioghist.head: History of Coronet Instructional Films
bioghist.p: Coronet Instructional Films were produced in the 1940s and 1950s to provide guidance for teenagers. The films were sold to schools and libraries. Most Coronet films were shot on Kodachrome but made and sold as black and white prints due to cost.

did.unittitle: Alumni Fun (Episode 8, Season 3)

scopecontent.head: Scope and content
scopecontent.p: Alumni Fun was a CBS game show that aired between 1963 and 1966. Alumni from colleges and universities across the United States competed to win money for scholarships. Each show featured two teams of three participants each; they answered questions in a variety of categories to receive points. Teams would continue in competition until defeated.
This episode features NYU competing against the University of Colorado.
